questions: What is motion ?
answers: A body is said to be in motion if it changes its position with respect to a reference point.

questions: How do we often perceive an object to be in motion ?
answers: When its position changes with time.

questions: Give an example when we infer the motion indirectly.
answers: We infer the motion of air by observing the movement of dust particles or leaves and branches of trees, or simply by feeling the blowing air on our face.

questions: What is essential to describe the position of an object ?
answers: We need to specify a reference point, called the origin.

questions: What is the simplest type of motion ?
answers: Motion in a straight line.

questions: Are rest and motion absolute or relative terms ?
answers: They are relative terms.

questions: Can an object be at rest as well as in motion at the same time ?
answers: Yes. An object may be at rest related to one object and at the same time it may be in motion related to another object.

questions: What indicates the motion of the earth ?
answers: The phenomena like coming of day and night indicate the motion of the earth.

questions: Is speed a scalar or vector quantity ?
answers: It is a scalar quantity.

questions: Give two examples of vector quantities.
answers: Velocity and acceleration.

questions: What do you mean by displacement ?
answers: The shortest distance moved by a body in the direction from initial to final position is called displacement.

questions: Is displacement a scalar quantity ?
answers: No, it is a vector quantity as it has both magnitude and direction.

questions: If the displacement of a body is zero, is it necessary that the distance covered by it is also zero ?
answers: No. When the body comes back to the same position after travelling a distance, its displacement is zero though it has travelled some distance.

questions: Q. 21.		Can the displacement be greater than the distance travelled by an object ?
answers: No, it is always either equal to or less than the distance travelled by the object.

questions: When do the distance and displacement of a moving object have the same magnitude ?
answers: The magnitude of distance and displacement of moving object are same when the object moves along the same straight line in the same fixed direction.

questions: What is the duration of the time interval needed for uniform or non-uniform motion ?
answers: It may be of any duration—small or large.

questions: Give two examples of non-uniform motion.
answers: A car moving in a crowded street and a person jogging in a park.

questions: Give the technical term used for the rate of motion of a body.
answers: Speed.

questions: What is the S.I. unit of speed ?
answers: Metre per sec i.e. ms–1.

questions: Is it true that to specify the speed of any object, we require only its magnitude ?
answers: Yes.

questions: How can the velocity of an object be changed ?
answers: It can be changed by changing either :  the object’s speed,  direction of motion, or  both.

questions: A body is moving with a velocity of 10 m/s. If the motion is uniform, what will be the velocity after 10 s ?
answers: As the motion is uniform, the velocity will remain 10 m/s after 10 s.

questions: Can a body have constant speed but variable velocity ?
answers: Yes, e.g. a body in uniform circular motion has constant speed but due to the change in the direction of motion, its velocity changes at every point.

questions: What is the rate of change of velocity called ?
answers: Acceleration.

questions: What is the S.I. unit of acceleration ?
answers: metre per 2 i.e. ms–2.

questions: When is the acceleration taken as negative ?
answers: When a body in motion stops to rest its acceleration is taken –ve, i.e., when final velocity is less than initial velocity.

questions: What is uniform acceleration ?
answers: Acceleration of an object is said to be uniform if it travels in a straight line and its velocity increases or decreases  by equal amounts in equal intervals of time.

questions: Give an example of a uniformly accelerated motion.
answers: Motion of a freely falling body.

questions: Give an example of non-uniform acceleration.
answers: A car travelling along a straight road increasing its speed by unequal amounts in equal intervals of time.

questions: How can the change in position of an object with time be represented ?
answers: It can be represented on the distance-time graph .

questions: On which axis are time and distance generally taken in a distance-time graph ?
answers: On the x - and y - axis respectively.

questions: How are the distance travelled by an object related to the time taken when an object travels equal distances in equal intervals of time ?
answers: In this case, distance travelled by the object is directly proportional to the time taken i.e., s ∝ t. 1

questions: What type of distance-time graph will you get for uniform speed ?
answers: It will be a straight line.
